title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: psychinterpreter package automatically interprets psychometric analysis results using Large Language Models (LLMs). LLMs AI systems (like ChatGPT, Claude, open-source alternatives) can understand generate human-like text. Instead manually examining complex statistical output guessing patterns represent, get clear, human-readable interpretations actionable insights. Currently supported analyses: Factor Analysis - Interpret factor loadings suggest meaningful factor names Planned analysis classes: Gaussian Mixture Models - Interpret cluster profiles Item Response Theory (IRT) - Interpret item diagnostics Cognitive Diagnostic Models (CDM) - Interpret Q-matrix patterns Use package : run psychometric analysis (e.g., factor analysis, clustering) Want automated, data-driven interpretations results Need quickly understand complex patterns data

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: starting, make sure : Analysis results - psych::fa(), lavaan::efa(), similar functions Variable descriptions - brief explanations variable measures language model - recommend Ollama (free, runs locally, offers cloud-powered models Ollama account)

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: ’s complete workflow factor analysis using Big Five personality data just lines:
code: library(psychinterpreter) library(psych) library(ollamar)  # 1. Run factor analysis fa_result <- psych::fa(bfi[,1:25], nfactors = 5, rotate = "oblimin")  # 2. Describe your variables var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("A1", "A2", "A3", ...),   description = c("Am indifferent to others", "Inquire about others", ...) )  # 3. Get LLM interpretation interpretation <- interpret(   fit_results = fa_result,   variable_info = var_info,   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # 4. View results print(interpretation) plot(interpretation)

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: tutorial demonstrates package using factor analysis, workflow applies analysis types become available. Let’s walk complete example using Big Five Inventory (BFI) personality data. Load packages ’ll need: BFI dataset contains 25 personality items measuring Big Five traits. ’s data looks like: item descriptions: Perform standard exploratory factor analysis 5 factors: View factor loadings: Create data frame mapping variable names descriptions: Now use interpret() get automatic factor interpretations: Note First time using Ollama? Install Ollama ollama.com ollamar package: install.packages("ollamar") Pull model: ollamar::pull("gpt-oss:20b-cloud") Start Ollama server running interpret() Print interpretation report: output shows: - Suggested factor names - variables load factor - brief interpretation factor represents View suggested factor names: Create visual representation factor loadings:  plot shows variables load strongly factor, making easy see factor structure glance. Save interpretation file:
code: # Install pacman if needed for easy package loading if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")  # Load packages pacman::p_load(   "psychinterpreter",  # This package   "psych",             # For factor analysis   "DT",        # For nice tables   "dplyr",             # For data manipulation   "pander"             # package for pretty printing ) # Load Big Five Inventory data data("bfi") data("bfi.dictionary")  # Keep only the 25 personality items (remove demographics) bfi_items <- bfi[, 1:25] bfi_dict <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ] head(bfi_items, 5) |>   as.data.frame() |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) bfi_dict |>   select(Item) |>   as.data.frame() |>   DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) fa_result <- psych::fa(   bfi_items,   nfactors = 5,   rotate = "oblimin",  # Oblique rotation   fm = "ml"            # Maximum likelihood ) # Extract and display loadings loadings_matrix <- unclass(fa_result$loadings) |>    as.data.frame()  round(loadings_matrix, 2) |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) variable_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(bfi_dict),   description = as.character(bfi_dict$Item),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  head(variable_info, 10) |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) interpretation <- interpret(   fit_results = fa_result,   variable_info = variable_info,   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" ) FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Number of factors: 5 Loading cutoff: 0.3 LLM used: ollama - gpt-oss:20b-cloud Elapsed time: 27.8  SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  • Factor 1 (9.6%): Emotional Instability • Factor 2 (7.7%): Empathetic Leadership • Factor 3 (7.4%): Introverted Reluctance • Factor 4 (7.7%): Conscientious Organization • Factor 5 (6.3%): Cognitive Openness  Total variance explained: 38.7%  FACTOR CORRELATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  ML2: ML5 = -.03, ML1 = .23, ML3 = -.21, ML4 = -.01 ML5: ML2 = -.03, ML1 = -.31, ML3 = .20, ML4 = .23 ML1: ML2 = .23, ML5 = -.31, ML3 = -.22, ML4 = -.17 ML3: ML2 = -.21, ML5 = .20, ML1 = -.22, ML4 = .20 ML4: ML2 = -.01, ML5 = .23, ML1 = -.17, ML3 = .20  DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Factor 1 (ML2) - Emotional Instability Number of significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 9.65% Factor Correlations: ML5 = -.03, ML1 = .23, ML3 = -.21, ML4 = -.01  Variables:   1. N1, Get angry easily. (, , .852)   2. N2, Get irritated easily. (, , .817)   3. N3, Have frequent mood swings. (, , .665)   4. N5, Panic easily. (, , .439)   5. N4, Often feel blue. (, , .413)  LLM Interpretation: Factor ML2 is labeled Emotional Instability. It is defined by strong positive loadings on all five Neuroticism items (N1–N5), all exceeding the 0.3 threshold. The pattern indicates a cohesive construct reflecting frequent negative affect—anger, irritability, mood swings, sadness, and panic. Cross‑loadings are negligible, supporting convergent validity. The factor shows modest positive correlation with ML1 (0.23) and weak negative correlation with ML5 (–0.31), suggesting it is distinct from social reticence and empathic traits. It captures a spectrum of reactive, unstable emotions.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 2 (ML5) - Empathetic Leadership Number of significant loadings: 7 Variance explained: 7.69% Factor Correlations: ML2 = -.03, ML1 = -.31, ML3 = .20, ML4 = .23  Variables:   1. A3, Know how to comfort others. (, , .668)   2. A2, Inquire about others' well-being. (, , .603)   3. A5, Make people feel at ease. (, , .577)   4. A4, Love children. (, , .456)   5. E4, Make friends easily. (, , .362)   6. A1, Am indifferent to the feelings of others. (, , -.360)   7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (, , .303)  LLM Interpretation: Factor ML5, named Empathetic Leadership, is characterized by sizable loadings on the Agreeableness cluster (A2 0.603, A3 0.668, A4 0.456, A5 0.577) and moderate loadings on Extraversion items (E3 0.303, E4 0.362). The high coefficients on caring and comfort‑oriented variables indicate strong empathic concern, while the social‑skill loadings reflect the ability to attract and influence others. Convergent validity is strong among the A‑items. Cross‑loadings to other factors are minimal, and correlation with ML2 is negative (–0.31), signalling that this empathic construct is distinct from emotional instability regard.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 3 (ML1) - Introverted Reluctance Number of significant loadings: 7 Variance explained: 7.36% Factor Correlations: ML2 = .23, ML5 = -.31, ML3 = -.22, ML4 = -.17  Variables:   1. E2, Find it difficult to approach others. (, , .667)   2. E1, Don't talk a lot. (, , .565)   3. E4, Make friends easily. (, , -.527)   4. N4, Often feel blue. (, , .420)   5. E5, Take charge. (, , -.394)   6. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (, , .357)   7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (, , -.341)  LLM Interpretation: Factor ML1, named Introverted Reluctance, shows high loadings on E1 0.565 and E2 0.667, capturing a tendency to avoid social contact. Negative loadings on E3 (–0.341), E4 (–0.527) and E5 (–0.394) further indicate reduced social initiative and influence. This pattern aligns with a low‑extraversion construct. The factor has a weak positive correlation with ML2 (0.23) yet negligible connections to ML5 and ML4, underscoring its distinctiveness from empathic and cognitive openness traits. Overall, ML1 quantifies social introversion and reticence and helps in understanding personality profiles for research analysis.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 4 (ML3) - Conscientious Organization Number of significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 7.71% Factor Correlations: ML2 = -.21, ML5 = .20, ML1 = -.22, ML4 = .20  Variables:   1. C4, Do things in a half-way manner. (, , -.643)   2. C2, Continue until everything is perfect. (, , .638)   3. C5, Waste my time. (, , -.570)   4. C3, Do things according to a plan. (, , .564)   5. C1, Am exacting in my work. (, , .532)  LLM Interpretation: Factor ML3, termed Conscientious Organization, is defined by strong positive loadings on C1 0.532, C2 0.638, and C3 0.564, and substantial negative loadings on C4 (–0.643) and C5 (–0.570). These coefficients capture a spectrum from orderly, planned behavior to indecisive or half‑hearted action. The factor shows modest negative correlation with ML1 (–0.22), indicating that conscientiousness is slightly inversely related to social reticence, but remains largely distinct from emotional and empathic factors. ML3 thus assesses the degree of dutiful organization versus disorganized execution within the personality structure.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 5 (ML4) - Cognitive Openness Number of significant loadings: 6 Variance explained: 6.25% Factor Correlations: ML2 = -.01, ML5 = .23, ML1 = -.17, ML3 = .20  Variables:   1. O3, Carry the conversation to a higher level. (, , .633)   2. O1, Am full of ideas. (, , .534)   3. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (, , -.522)   4. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (, , -.441)   5. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (, , .379)   6. E3, Know how to captivate people. (, , .315)  LLM Interpretation: Factor ML4, titled Cognitive Openness, boasts large positive loadings on O1 0.534, O3 0.633, and O4 0.379, while O2 (–0.441) and O5 (–0.522) load negatively. This pattern differentiates individuals who generate ideas, deepen conversations, and reflect from those who avoid challenging material or probe deeply. Moderate E3 and E5 loadings link subtle social skill aspects. Correlations with ML5 (0.23) and ML2 (–0.01) confirm that cognitive openness is distinct yet moderately related to empathy and emotional stability. ML4 captures intellectual curiosity and openness to experience and perception within personality landscape.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  CROSS-LOADING VARIABLES ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Variables loading on multiple factors (>= 0.3): - E3: ML5 (.303), ML1 (-.341), ML4 (.315) - E4: ML5 (.362), ML1 (-.527) - N4: ML2 (.413), ML1 (.420) - O4: ML1 (.357), ML4 (.379) print(interpretation) FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Number of factors: 5 Loading cutoff: 0.3 LLM used: ollama - gpt-oss:20b-cloud Elapsed time: 27.8  SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  • Factor 1 (9.6%): Emotional Instability • Factor 2 (7.7%): Empathetic Leadership • Factor 3 (7.4%): Introverted Reluctance • Factor 4 (7.7%): Conscientious Organization • Factor 5 (6.3%): Cognitive Openness  Total variance explained: 38.7%  FACTOR CORRELATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  ML2: ML5 = -.03, ML1 = .23, ML3 = -.21, ML4 = -.01 ML5: ML2 = -.03, ML1 = -.31, ML3 = .20, ML4 = .23 ML1: ML2 = .23, ML5 = -.31, ML3 = -.22, ML4 = -.17 ML3: ML2 = -.21, ML5 = .20, ML1 = -.22, ML4 = .20 ML4: ML2 = -.01, ML5 = .23, ML1 = -.17, ML3 = .20  DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Factor 1 (ML2) - Emotional Instability Number of significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 9.65% Factor Correlations: ML5 = -.03, ML1 = .23, ML3 = -.21, ML4 = -.01  Variables:   1. title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Load packages ’ll need:
code: # Install pacman if needed for easy package loading if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")  # Load packages pacman::p_load(   "psychinterpreter",  # This package   "psych",             # For factor analysis   "DT",        # For nice tables   "dplyr",             # For data manipulation   "pander"             # package for pretty printing )

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: BFI dataset contains 25 personality items measuring Big Five traits. ’s data looks like: item descriptions:
code: # Load Big Five Inventory data data("bfi") data("bfi.dictionary")  # Keep only the 25 personality items (remove demographics) bfi_items <- bfi[, 1:25] bfi_dict <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ] head(bfi_items, 5) |>   as.data.frame() |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) bfi_dict |>   select(Item) |>   as.data.frame() |>   DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Perform standard exploratory factor analysis 5 factors: View factor loadings:
code: fa_result <- psych::fa(   bfi_items,   nfactors = 5,   rotate = "oblimin",  # Oblique rotation   fm = "ml"            # Maximum likelihood ) # Extract and display loadings loadings_matrix <- unclass(fa_result$loadings) |>    as.data.frame()  round(loadings_matrix, 2) |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Create data frame mapping variable names descriptions:
code: variable_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(bfi_dict),   description = as.character(bfi_dict$Item),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  head(variable_info, 10) |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

ML4 captures intellectual curiosity and openness to experience and perception within personality landscape.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  CROSS-LOADING VARIABLES ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Variables loading on multiple factors (>= 0.3): - E3: ML5 (.303), ML1 (-.341), ML4 (.315) - E4: ML5 (.362), ML1 (-.527) - N4: ML2 (.413), ML1 (.420) - O4: ML1 (.357), ML4 (.379)

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Print interpretation report: output shows: - Suggested factor names - variables load factor - brief interpretation factor represents View suggested factor names:
code: print(interpretation) FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Number of factors: 5 Loading cutoff: 0.3 LLM used: ollama - gpt-oss:20b-cloud Elapsed time: 27.8  SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  • Factor 1 (9.6%): Emotional Instability • Factor 2 (7.7%): Empathetic Leadership • Factor 3 (7.4%): Introverted Reluctance • Factor 4 (7.7%): Conscientious Organization • Factor 5 (6.3%): Cognitive Openness  Total variance explained: 38.7%  FACTOR CORRELATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  ML2: ML5 = -.03, ML1 = .23, ML3 = -.21, ML4 = -.01 ML5: ML2 = -.03, ML1 = -.31, ML3 = .20, ML4 = .23 ML1: ML2 = .23, ML5 = -.31, ML3 = -.22, ML4 = -.17 ML3: ML2 = -.21, ML5 = .20, ML1 = -.22, ML4 = .20 ML4: ML2 = -.01, ML5 = .23, ML1 = -.17, ML3 = .20  DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Factor 1 (ML2) - Emotional Instability Number of significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 9.65% Factor Correlations: ML5 = -.03, ML1 = .23, ML3 = -.21, ML4 = -.01  Variables:   1. N1, Get angry easily. (, , .852)   2. N2, Get irritated easily. (, , .817)   3. N3, Have frequent mood swings. (, , .665)   4. N5, Panic easily. (, , .439)   5. N4, Often feel blue. (, , .413)  LLM Interpretation: Factor ML2 is labeled Emotional Instability. It is defined by strong positive loadings on all five Neuroticism items (N1–N5), all exceeding the 0.3 threshold. The pattern indicates a cohesive construct reflecting frequent negative affect—anger, irritability, mood swings, sadness, and panic. Cross‑loadings are negligible, supporting convergent validity. The factor shows modest positive correlation with ML1 (0.23) and weak negative correlation with ML5 (–0.31), suggesting it is distinct from social reticence and empathic traits. It captures a spectrum of reactive, unstable emotions.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 2 (ML5) - Empathetic Leadership Number of significant loadings: 7 Variance explained: 7.69% Factor Correlations: ML2 = -.03, ML1 = -.31, ML3 = .20, ML4 = .23  Variables:   1. A3, Know how to comfort others. (, , .668)   2. A2, Inquire about others' well-being. (, , .603)   3. A5, Make people feel at ease. (, , .577)   4. A4, Love children. (, , .456)   5. E4, Make friends easily. (, , .362)   6. A1, Am indifferent to the feelings of others. (, , -.360)   7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (, , .303)  LLM Interpretation: Factor ML5, named Empathetic Leadership, is characterized by sizable loadings on the Agreeableness cluster (A2 0.603, A3 0.668, A4 0.456, A5 0.577) and moderate loadings on Extraversion items (E3 0.303, E4 0.362). The high coefficients on caring and comfort‑oriented variables indicate strong empathic concern, while the social‑skill loadings reflect the ability to attract and influence others. Convergent validity is strong among the A‑items. Cross‑loadings to other factors are minimal, and correlation with ML2 is negative (–0.31), signalling that this empathic construct is distinct from emotional instability regard.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 3 (ML1) - Introverted Reluctance Number of significant loadings: 7 Variance explained: 7.36% Factor Correlations: ML2 = .23, ML5 = -.31, ML3 = -.22, ML4 = -.17  Variables:   1. E2, Find it difficult to approach others. (, , .667)   2. E1, Don't talk a lot. (, , .565)   3. E4, Make friends easily. (, , -.527)   4. N4, Often feel blue. (, , .420)   5. E5, Take charge. (, , -.394)   6. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (, , .357)   7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (, , -.341)  LLM Interpretation: Factor ML1, named Introverted Reluctance, shows high loadings on E1 0.565 and E2 0.667, capturing a tendency to avoid social contact. Negative loadings on E3 (–0.341), E4 (–0.527) and E5 (–0.394) further indicate reduced social initiative and influence. This pattern aligns with a low‑extraversion construct. The factor has a weak positive correlation with ML2 (0.23) yet negligible connections to ML5 and ML4, underscoring its distinctiveness from empathic and cognitive openness traits. Overall, ML1 quantifies social introversion and reticence and helps in understanding personality profiles for research analysis.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 4 (ML3) - Conscientious Organization Number of significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 7.71% Factor Correlations: ML2 = -.21, ML5 = .20, ML1 = -.22, ML4 = .20  Variables:   1. C4, Do things in a half-way manner. (, , -.643)   2. C2, Continue until everything is perfect. (, , .638)   3. C5, Waste my time. (, , -.570)   4. C3, Do things according to a plan. (, , .564)   5. C1, Am exacting in my work. (, , .532)  LLM Interpretation: Factor ML3, termed Conscientious Organization, is defined by strong positive loadings on C1 0.532, C2 0.638, and C3 0.564, and substantial negative loadings on C4 (–0.643) and C5 (–0.570). These coefficients capture a spectrum from orderly, planned behavior to indecisive or half‑hearted action. The factor shows modest negative correlation with ML1 (–0.22), indicating that conscientiousness is slightly inversely related to social reticence, but remains largely distinct from emotional and empathic factors. ML3 thus assesses the degree of dutiful organization versus disorganized execution within the personality structure.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 5 (ML4) - Cognitive Openness Number of significant loadings: 6 Variance explained: 6.25% Factor Correlations: ML2 = -.01, ML5 = .23, ML1 = -.17, ML3 = .20  Variables:   1. O3, Carry the conversation to a higher level. (, , .633)   2. O1, Am full of ideas. (, , .534)   3. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (, , -.522)   4. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (, , -.441)   5. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (, , .379)   6. E3, Know how to captivate people. (, , .315)  LLM Interpretation: Factor ML4, titled Cognitive Openness, boasts large positive loadings on O1 0.534, O3 0.633, and O4 0.379, while O2 (–0.441) and O5 (–0.522) load negatively. This pattern differentiates individuals who generate ideas, deepen conversations, and reflect from those who avoid challenging material or probe deeply. Moderate E3 and E5 loadings link subtle social skill aspects. Correlations with ML5 (0.23) and ML2 (–0.01) confirm that cognitive openness is distinct yet moderately related to empathy and emotional stability. ML4 captures intellectual curiosity and openness to experience and perception within personality landscape.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  CROSS-LOADING VARIABLES ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Variables loading on multiple factors (>= 0.3): - E3: ML5 (.303), ML1 (-.341), ML4 (.315) - E4: ML5 (.362), ML1 (-.527) - N4: ML2 (.413), ML1 (.420) - O4: ML1 (.357), ML4 (.379) interpretation$suggested_names |>   unlist() |>  data.frame(Suggested_Factor_Name = _) |>   DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE), colnames = "Suggested Factor Name")

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Q: LLM interpretation seems wrong? LLM bases interpretations variable descriptions statistical results. can: Provide better, descriptive variable descriptions Use bigger LLM. Small models may struggle task structured output requirements. Adjust cutoff hide_low_loadings parameters change results included Add context additional_info parameter Q: Can use different LLMs? Yes! package supports providers supported ellmer package, example: Ollama (local, free): provider = "ollama" OpenAI (API key required): provider = "openai" Anthropic Claude (API key required): provider = "anthropic" Q: set API keys OpenAI Anthropic? Also refer documentation ellmer https://ellmer.tidyverse.org/ package.
code: # Add to your .Renviron file: Sys.setenv(OPENAI_API_KEY = "your-key-here") Sys.setenv(ANTHROPIC_API_KEY = "your-key-here")

title: interpret() Usage Patterns
text: use Ollama, need make sure start server running . Test connection: use model “gpt-oss:20b-cloud”, needs installed. Since cloud-powered model, need account Ollama logged run model.
code: packages <- c(   "psychinterpreter",   "ellmer",   "ollamar",   "psych",   "lavaan",   "mirt",   "dplyr",   "here",   "DT",   "pander" ) # Load required packages using pacman if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman") Loading required package: pacman pacman::p_load(char = packages) #!/bin/bash  # Check if port 11434 (default Ollama port) is in use if netstat -ano | grep 11434 > /dev/null; then     echo "Ollama is already running." else     echo "Starting Ollama..."     ollama serve fi Ollama is already running. system2("ollama serve", wait = FALSE) Warning in system2("ollama serve", wait = FALSE): '"ollama serve"' not found # test the connection to the Ollama server ollamar::test_connection() Ollama local server running <httr2_response> GET http://localhost:11434/ Status: 200 OK Content-Type: text/plain Body: In memory (17 bytes) # pull the model from ollama if it is not already installed if (!"gpt-oss:20b-cloud" %in% ollamar::list_models()$name) {   ollamar::pull("gpt-oss:20b-cloud") }

title: interpret() Usage Patterns
text: use Ollama, need make sure start server running . Test connection: use model “gpt-oss:20b-cloud”, needs installed. Since cloud-powered model, need account Ollama logged run model.
code: #!/bin/bash  # Check if port 11434 (default Ollama port) is in use if netstat -ano | grep 11434 > /dev/null; then     echo "Ollama is already running." else     echo "Starting Ollama..."     ollama serve fi Ollama is already running. system2("ollama serve", wait = FALSE) Warning in system2("ollama serve", wait = FALSE): '"ollama serve"' not found # test the connection to the Ollama server ollamar::test_connection() Ollama local server running <httr2_response> GET http://localhost:11434/ Status: 200 OK Content-Type: text/plain Body: In memory (17 bytes) # pull the model from ollama if it is not already installed if (!"gpt-oss:20b-cloud" %in% ollamar::list_models()$name) {   ollamar::pull("gpt-oss:20b-cloud") }

title: interpret() Usage Patterns
code: fa_model <- fa(mtcars[,1:4], nfactors = 2, rotate = "oblimin")  var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("mpg", "cyl", "disp", "hp"),   description = c("Miles per gallon", "Cylinders", "Displacement", "Horsepower") )

title: interpret() Usage Patterns
text: Automatically extracts model components fitted objects. custom data structures manual extraction. FA, provide loadings (required) optionally factor_cor_mat: Reuse chat session across analyses save tokens. can check total global token usage:
code: interpret(   fit_results = fa_model,   variable_info = var_info,   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",   word_limit = 50 ) ℹ Starting fa interpretation... ℹ Creating temporary chat session... ℹ Building prompt... ℹ Querying LLM... ℹ Parsing LLM response... ℹ Creating diagnostics... ℹ Building report... ✔ Interpretation complete! FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Number of factors: 2 Loading cutoff: 0.3 LLM used: ollama - gpt-oss:20b-cloud Elapsed time: 7.67  SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  • Factor 1 (84%): Fuel Efficiency vs Power • Factor 2 (1.7%): Residual Noise (n.s.)  Total variance explained: 85.7%  FACTOR CORRELATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  MR1: MR2 = .03 MR2: MR1 = .03  DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Factor 1 (MR1) - Fuel Efficiency vs Power Number of significant loadings: 4 Variance explained: 84.03% Factor Correlations: MR2 = .03  Variables:   1. disp, Displacement (, , .955)   2. cyl, Cylinders (, , .953)   3. mpg, Miles per gallon (, , -.893)   4. hp, Horsepower (, , .862)  LLM Interpretation: MR1 captures the core technical trade‑off in automobiles: larger displacement, more cylinders, and higher horsepower strengthen power, while higher miles‑per‑gallon inversely represents fuel efficiency. The dominant negative loading on mpg and strong positive loadings on power‑related variables illustrate the classic power‑versus‑economy dilemma.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 2 (MR2) - Residual Noise (n.s.) Number of significant loadings: 0 Variance explained: 1.7% Factor Correlations: MR1 = .03  WARNING: No variables load above cutoff (0.3). Emergency rule applied: using top 2 variable(s) below cutoff for interpretation.  Variables:   1. hp, Horsepower (, , .195)   2. disp, Displacement (, , -.172)  LLM Interpretation: MR2 explains only 1.7% of variance and shows negligible loadings on all measures; it represents residual noise or an unstructured factor. Its near‑zero correlation with MR1 confirms it captures a construct that is essentially unrelated to power or fuel efficiency.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Number of factors: 2 Loading cutoff: 0.3 LLM used: ollama - gpt-oss:20b-cloud Elapsed time: 7.67  SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  • Factor 1 (84%): Fuel Efficiency vs Power • Factor 2 (1.7%): Residual Noise (n.s.)  Total variance explained: 85.7%  FACTOR CORRELATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  MR1: MR2 = .03 MR2: MR1 = .03  DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Factor 1 (MR1) - Fuel Efficiency vs Power Number of significant loadings: 4 Variance explained: 84.03% Factor Correlations: MR2 = .03  Variables:   1. disp, Displacement (, , .955)   2. cyl, Cylinders (, , .953)   3. mpg, Miles per gallon (, , -.893)   4. hp, Horsepower (, , .862)  LLM Interpretation: MR1 captures the core technical trade‑off in automobiles: larger displacement, more cylinders, and higher horsepower strengthen power, while higher miles‑per‑gallon inversely represents fuel efficiency. The dominant negative loading on mpg and strong positive loadings on power‑related variables illustrate the classic power‑versus‑economy dilemma.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 2 (MR2) - Residual Noise (n.s.) Number of significant loadings: 0 Variance explained: 1.7% Factor Correlations: MR1 = .03  WARNING: No variables load above cutoff (0.3). Emergency rule applied: using top 2 variable(s) below cutoff for interpretation.  Variables:   1. hp, Horsepower (, , .195)   2. disp, Displacement (, , -.172)  LLM Interpretation: MR2 explains only 1.7% of variance and shows negligible loadings on all measures; it represents residual noise or an unstructured factor. Its near‑zero correlation with MR1 confirms it captures a construct that is essentially unrelated to power or fuel efficiency.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ loadings_matrix <- fa_model$loadings factor_cor_mat <- fa_model$Phi  interpret(   fit_results = list(loadings = loadings_matrix, factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat),   variable_info = var_info,   model_type = "fa",   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",   word_limit = 50 ) ℹ Starting fa interpretation... ℹ Creating temporary chat session... ℹ Building prompt... ℹ Querying LLM... ℹ Parsing LLM response... ℹ Creating diagnostics... ℹ Building report... ✔ Interpretation complete! FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Number of factors: 2 Loading cutoff: 0.3 LLM used: ollama - gpt-oss:20b-cloud Elapsed time: 8.96  SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  • Factor 1 (84%): Engine Performance • Factor 2 (1.7%): Residual Variation (n.s.)  Total variance explained: 85.7%  FACTOR CORRELATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  MR1: MR2 = .03 MR2: MR1 = .03  DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Factor 1 (MR1) - Engine Performance Number of significant loadings: 4 Variance explained: 84.03% Factor Correlations: MR2 = .03  Variables:   1. disp, Displacement (, , .955)   2. cyl, Cylinders (, , .953)   3. mpg, Miles per gallon (, , -.893)   4. hp, Horsepower (, , .862)  LLM Interpretation: This factor represents engine performance, capturing key power attributes such as cylinders, displacement, and horsepower, while inversely related to fuel efficiency (mpg). The high positive loadings on power variables and negative mpg loading indicate a trade‑off between power output and fuel economy. It explains 84 % of variance.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 2 (MR2) - Residual Variation (n.s.) Number of significant loadings: 0 Variance explained: 1.7% Factor Correlations: MR1 = .03  WARNING: No variables load above cutoff (0.3). Variables:   1. hp, Horsepower (, , .195)   2. disp, Displacement (, , -.172)  LLM Interpretation: Despite low loadings, the factor captures a very weak association between horsepower and displacement, reflecting residual variance not explained by MR1. Its correlations with MR1 are negligible (.03), indicating it represents distinct, minor variation. It explains only 1.7 % of variance.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ chat <- chat_session(model_type = "fa",                      provider = "ollama",                      model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud") result1 <- interpret(   chat_session = chat,   fit_results = fa_model,   variable_info = var_info,   word_limit = 50,   silent = 1 ) ℹ Starting fa interpretation... ℹ Building prompt... ℹ Querying LLM... ℹ Parsing LLM response... ℹ Creating diagnostics... ℹ Building report... ✔ Interpretation complete! result2 <- interpret(   chat_session = chat,   fit_results = list(loadings = loadings_matrix, factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat),   variable_info = var_info,   word_limit = 50,   silent = 1 ) ℹ Starting fa interpretation... ℹ Building prompt... ℹ Querying LLM... ℹ Parsing LLM response... ℹ Creating diagnostics... ℹ Building report... ✔ Interpretation complete! print(chat) Factor Analysis Chat Session Provider: ollama Model: gpt-oss:20b-cloud Created: 2025-11-11 18:06:41.801799 Interpretations run: 2 Total tokens - Input: 1652 , Output: 1900

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Purpose: Quick reference Claude Code helping users psychinterpreter R package. technical/architectural details: See dev/DEVELOPER_GUIDE.md Status: Phase 2 Refactoring Complete (2025-11-10) - See dev/DEVELOPER_GUIDE.md section 4.2 details IMPORTANT API CHANGES: - Phase 1 (2025-11-09): - fit_results renamed fit_results - provider model renamed provider model - New config objects: llm_args(), fa_args(), output_args() - Phase 2 (2025-11-10): - interpret_fa() removed entirely (functionality now S3 generic build_model_data()) - New architecture: interpret() → interpret_core() → build_model_data.fa() - 169 tests passing new S3 generic system - Phase 3 (2025-11-11): - fa_args() renamed interpretation_args(model_type, ...) - Model-type-aware configuration system - FA-specific functions moved shared utilities FA-specific files - Export system refactored S3 generic pattern

title: CLAUDE.md
text: : Automates interpretation exploratory factor analysis (EFA) results using Large Language Models via ellmer package. Main Entry Points: - interpret() - Universal generic (public API interpretations) - chat_session() - Create persistent LLM session (saves ~40-60% tokens multiple analyses) Standards Examples/Tests: - Always use provider = "ollama" model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" - LLM tests: word_limit = 20 (minimum allowed) token efficiency Documentation Structure: - CLAUDE.md (file): Usage guide quick reference Claude Code sessions - dev/DEVELOPER_GUIDE.md: Technical architecture implementation details maintainers - dev/TESTING_GUIDELINES.md: Testing standards patterns - dev/templates/: Ready--copy code templates implementing new model types (GM, IRT, CDM) - dev/MODEL_IMPLEMENTATION_GUIDE.md: Conceptual guide new model type implementation

title: CLAUDE.md
code: library(psychinterpreter)  # 1. Run factor analysis fa_result <- psych::fa(data, nfactors = 3)  # 2. Prepare variable descriptions var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("var1", "var2", ...),   description = c("Description of variable 1", "Description of variable 2", ...) )  # 3. Get interpretation interpretation <- interpret(   fit_results = fa_result,   variable_info = var_info,   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # 4. View and export results print(interpretation)                                    # Print report plot(interpretation)                                     # Visualize loadings export_interpretation(interpretation, "results.md", "md") # Export

title: Create Analysis Chat Session — chat_session
text: model_type Character. Type analysis: "fa" (factor analysis), "gm" (gaussian mixture), "irt" (item response theory), "cdm" (cognitive diagnosis model) provider Character. LLM provider (e.g., "anthropic", "openai", "ollama") model Character. Model name (e.g., "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001") system_prompt Character NULL. Optional custom system prompt text override model-specific default system prompt. Use provide institution- project-specific framing LLM (e.g., preferred terminology, audience level, reporting conventions). NULL, model-specific default system prompt used (default = NULL). params List. ellmer parameters (temperature, etc.). Default uses ellmer::params() echo Character. Echo level ("none", "output", ""). Default "none" word_limit Integer. Word limit interpretations (used system_prompt NULL). Default 100.

title: Create Analysis Chat Session — chat_session
text: chat_session object containing persistent chat session

title: Create Analysis Chat Session — chat_session
text: chat_session object stores: persistent ellmer chat session model-specific system prompt already loaded Model type, provider, model information Token usage tracking (cumulative input/output tokens across interpretations) Session metadata (number interpretations run, creation timestamp) allows efficient reuse across multiple interpretations without resending system prompt time. Token Tracking Note: package tracks per-interpretation token counts using roles returned ellmer::chat$get_tokens() (user/assistant). providers ellmer wrapper consistently expose system/system_prompt token counts (appears upstream limitation/bug). avoid incorrect cumulative accounting (double-counting negative accumulation), chat_session intentionally include system_prompt tokens package-level cumulative counters (total_input_tokens / total_output_tokens). require provider-specific view includes system prompt tokens, call chat$chat$get_tokens(include_system_prompt = TRUE) directly — note results may vary across providers.

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: fit_results One : Fitted model object: psych package: fa(), principal() lavaan package: cfa(), sem(), efa() mirt package: mirt() Structured list model components: FA: list(loadings = matrix, factor_cor_mat = matrix) list(loadings = matrix) (loadings factor_cor_mat can matrices data.frames) GM: yet implemented IRT: yet implemented CDM: yet implemented chat_session Optional. chat_session object created chat_session token-efficient multi-analysis workflows (default = NULL). model_type Character. Type analysis ("fa", "gm", "irt", "cdm"). Required using structured list without chat_session. Automatically inferred chat_session provided (default = NULL). provider Character. LLM provider (e.g., "openai", "anthropic", "ollama", "gemini"). Required chat_session NULL. Top-level convenience parameter (default = NULL). model Character. Specific model use (e.g., "gpt-4o-mini", "claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022", "gemma2:9b"). NULL, uses provider default. Top-level convenience parameter (default = NULL). llm_args List llm_args object. LLM configuration settings. Can created llm_args passed plain list. Contains: system_prompt, params, word_limit, interpretation_guidelines, additional_info, echo. provider/model provided top-level, override values llm_args (default = NULL). interpretation_args List interpretation_args object. Model-specific interpretation configuration. Can created interpretation_args passed plain list. Contents vary model type. FA: cutoff, n_emergency, hide_low_loadings, sort_loadings, factor_cor_mat (default = NULL). output_args List output_args object. Output configuration settings. Can created output_args passed plain list. Contains: format, heading_level, suppress_heading, max_line_length, silent (default = NULL). ... Additional arguments passed model-specific methods. Model-specific methods may require: variable_info: Data frame 'variable' 'description' columns (required FA)

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: Model-specific interpretation object: FA: fa_interpretation (see interpret) Future: gm_interpretation, irt_interpretation, etc.

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: arguments named prevent positional confusion. function detects pattern using based arguments provided.

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: Pattern 1: Fitted Model Object Automatically extracts model components fitted objects. Pattern 2: Structured List custom data structures manual extraction. FA, provide loadings (required) optionally factor_cor_mat: Pattern 3: Chat Session (Token-Efficient) Reuse chat session across analyses save tokens. Pattern 4: Configuration Objects (Advanced) Use configuration objects reusable settings cleaner code.
code: interpret(   fit_results = fa_model,   variable_info = var_info,   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" ) interpret(   fit_results = list(     loadings = loadings_matrix,     factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat   ),   variable_info = var_info,   model_type = "fa" ) chat <- chat_session(model_type = "fa", provider = "ollama", model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud") result1 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = model1, variable_info = var_info1) result2 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = model2, variable_info = var_info2) # Create configuration objects interp_config <- interpretation_args(model_type = "fa", cutoff = 0.4, n_emergency = 2) llm_config <- llm_args(word_limit = 100, additional_info = "Study context") output_config <- output_args(output_format = "markdown", silent = 1)  # Use in interpret() call interpret(   fit_results = fa_model,   variable_info = var_info,   interpretation_args = interp_config,   llm_args = llm_config,   output_args = output_config,   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Or mix config objects with direct parameters (direct parameters override) interpret(   fit_results = fa_model,   variable_info = var_info,   interpretation_args = interp_config,   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",   word_limit = 150  # Overrides llm_config if it were provided )

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: fa (Factor Analysis): psych::fa(), psych::principal(), lavaan::cfa/efa(), mirt::mirt() gm (Gaussian Mixture): yet implemented irt (Item Response Theory): yet implemented cdm (Cognitive Diagnosis Models): yet implemented

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: provider model exposed top-level parameters convenience, dual interface pattern allows argument passed either directly respective configuration object (llm_args, interpretation_args, output_args). keeps primary signature clean maintaining flexibility

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(psych) fa_model <- fa(mtcars[,1:4], nfactors = 2, rotate = "oblimin")  var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("mpg", "cyl", "disp", "hp"),   description = c("Miles per gallon", "Cylinders", "Displacement", "Horsepower") )  # Pattern 1: Fitted model result1 <- interpret(   fit_results = fa_model,   variable_info = var_info,   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Pattern 2: Structured list # Extract loadings from fitted model loadings <- as.data.frame(unclass(fa_model$loadings))  # Option A: Loadings only (orthogonal rotation) result2a <- interpret(   fit_results = list(loadings = loadings),   variable_info = var_info,   model_type = "fa",   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Option B: Loadings + factor correlations (oblique rotation) result2b <- interpret(   fit_results = list(     loadings = loadings,     factor_cor_mat = fa_model$Phi   ),   variable_info = var_info,   model_type = "fa",   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Pattern 3: Chat session (token-efficient for multiple analyses) chat <- chat_session(model_type = "fa", provider = "ollama", model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud") result3a <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa_model, variable_info = var_info) result3b <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa_model2, variable_info = var_info2) print(chat)  # Check token usage } # }

title: Base Interpretation Class Structure — interpretation

title: Base Interpretation Class Structure — interpretation
text: model-specific interpretation classes inherit base class. Common fields across interpretation types: model_type: Character. Type analysis ("fa", "gm", "irt", "cdm") component_summaries: List. Summaries factors/clusters/items/attributes suggested_names: List. LLM-generated names components interpretations: List. LLM-generated interpretations llm_info: List. Provider, model, token information chat: Chat session object diagnostics: List. Model-specific diagnostic information report: Character. Formatted text report elapsed_time: Numeric. Processing time seconds params: List. Analysis parameters

title: Create Model-Specific Interpretation Configuration — interpretation_args
text: Factor Analysis (model_type = "fa"): cutoff: Numeric. Minimum loading value consider significant (default = 0.3) n_emergency: Integer. factor loadings cutoff, use top N highest loadings. 0, factors significant loadings labeled "undefined" (default = 2) hide_low_loadings: Logical. TRUE, variables loadings cutoff included LLM prompt (default = FALSE) sort_loadings: Logical. Sort variables loading strength within factors (default = TRUE) Note: Factor correlation matrices passed via fit_results parameter list structure: list(loadings = ..., factor_cor_mat = ...), via interpretation_args.

text: x fa_interpretation object interpret() max_line_length Integer. Maximum line length text wrapping (default = 80). Lines longer wrapped word boundaries preserving formatting like headers, indentation, separators. applies cli format. output_format Character. Output format: "cli", "markdown", NULL (default = NULL). NULL, uses existing report format. specified, regenerates report specified format using stored analysis results. heading_level Integer. Starting heading level markdown output (default = 1). used output_format = "markdown". suppress_heading Logical.
